Hi Ben, 
We have many resources on the Knowledge Network related to the kind of public-private partnerships you are interested in. 
This article explains the different basic types of public-private partnerships that you pursue in your situation. http://icma.org/en/international/resources/insights/Article/101962/PublicPrivate_Partnership_Structures_and_Arrangements
I would highly encourage you to check out the Knowledge Network's Topic page on Public-Private Partnerships. If you go to the articles section(http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/topics/kn/topic_articles/222/publicprivate_partnerships) the documents section (http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/topics/kn/topic_documents/222/publicprivate_partnerships) or the blogs and questions section you will find other local governments who had similar situations and see what they did through case studies. 
I hope you find these resources useful and feel free to ask more questions as you work on your local government's specific public-private partnership plan. 
Best, 
Robin Saywitz 
ICMA Knowledge Network Intern 
rsaywitz@icma.org

author: Ben Boike
text:
I am wondering if a city out there has experience in purchasing blighted/foreclosed homes, paying for demolition of the site and contracting a builder to build a new home.  
The City of West St. Paul (MN, first ring suburb) purchased and demolished around 15 homes in 2009 and 2010.  We were successful in selling the majority of the lots to builders who have built new homes and sold them privately, however we have a handful of lots left that have not sold.  
As a result, we are considering the option of fronting the construction cost by contracting the construction with a local builder with the idea that it would be more of an attractive deal for the builder (less risky).
If anyone has experience with something similar, good or bad, we would love to hear from you.
Thanks,
Ben Boike
Assistant Comm. Dev. Dir.
West St. Paul, MN
651-552-4134
title: Housing Redevelopment - Public/Private Partnership
